byline.contributor: Hisako Ueno and Maki Nakamatsu contributed reporting.

abstract: Japanese Parliament passes legislation that authorizes its military to conduct overseas combat missions, ending decades-old policy that only allowed use of military force in defense of country; vote is victory for Prime Min Shinzo Abe, but analysts say political fight to secure its passage along with protests of effort could affect his standing among public.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe succeeded in his effort to move beyond the postwar pacifism that has kept his country out of conflicts.

headline.main: Japan’s Parliament Approves Overseas Combat Role for Military
headline.print_headline: Japan Approves Law to Allow Broader Role for Military

snippet: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe succeeded in his effort to move beyond the postwar pacifism that has kept his country out of conflicts.
